Award.AwardTitle: Digitization TCN: Collaborative Research: Fossil Insect Collaborative: A Deep-Time Approach to Studying Diversification and Response to Environmental Change
Award.AbstractNarration:
Fossil insects provide a unique deep-time record of ecological and evolutionary response to past environmental changes and therefore are invaluable for understanding the impacts of climate change on the current biodiversity crisis. Given current models of future climate change and the important role that insects play in human society (biodiversity, pests, pollination, vectors of disease) the ability to access these data and make predictions about future insect populations becomes even more urgent. The Fossil Insect Collaborative will make available all the major collections of fossil insect specimens in the United States by creating electronic specimen records consisting of digital images and associated collection data.

The digitized fossil insect collections will be made broadly accessible to the research community, K-16 education, government and industry, the general public, and the media through the project website and a central site integrating all the paleobiological Thematic Collections Networks called iDigPaleo. Mobile apps and activities that allow a wide variety of users to experience and interact directly with the collections data will be developed. This award is made as part of the National Resource for Digitization of Biological Collections through the Advancing Digitization of Biological Collections program and all data resulting from this award will be available through the national resource (iDigBio.org).

POR.DRECONTENT:
In total, during the grant we have produced 42,910 images accounting for 37,835 specimens of insect fossils, all of which are databased. The entire catalogued MCZ Insect Fossil Collection is now digitized, the largest such collection in the world, which joins those of the other 6 participating non-federal U.S. institutions housing fossil insect collections, in providing free access to their digitized collections. 

 

 These numbers are more than twice the digitization goals that were originally proposed for the MCZ (15,000 specimens). The specimens are both impressions in stone, and inclusions in amber. These MCZ insect fossils represent the entire history of insect diversification on earth over 250 million years. They include some of the most iconic specimens known, such as the largest insect wing ever found, that of Meganeuropsis americana, a nearly meter wide Paleozoic creature discovered by MCZ curator Frank Carpenter in the 1930's that led to widespread appreciation of the enormous body sizes of insects of that period. The specimen was featured in the David Attenborough film, Life in the Undergrowth. 

 

All of the images and associated data are freely available to the public online through the digitized biological collections portal at IDigBio.org.  In the process of producing these images, we verified the scientific type status of every specimen. We discovered an unreturned loan of some 400 Baltic Amber specimens, and hand-carried them to their owner, the museum at the University of Gottingen in Germany. 

 

Three young employees (two men and one woman) were trained in the appropriate museum imaging and curation techniques, building human capacity. Multiple scientist visitors to the fossil collections were hosted during the grant period, and images were shared with scientists abroad on request. Several tours were given to groups of students and visitors to the museum, and images and information were shared with popular news outlets, including the Harvard Gazette. The postdoctoral fellow, insect fossil expert Dr. Ricardo Perez de la Fuente, was given deep training in museum curation and also gained deep familiarity with the fossil collections of the MCZ.
